Title: Carreno Busta halts Hurkacz finals win streak with Montreal triumph
Text:
The 23rd-ranked Spaniard beat eighth-seeded Hurkacz 3-6, 6-3, 6-3 to become the first unseeded winner in Canada in two decades.
Carreno Busta notched his seventh ATP title, but his first in an elite Masters 1000 event in his first opportunity.
"It's an amazing feeling to be a Masters 1000 winner," Carreno Busta said. "It's the best title of my career for sure.
"I know that during all the week we worked very hard, also the weeks before. It's very important to be very positive all the time. It's not my best season this year. I lost some matches that probably other seasons I didn't lose, but I just tried to continue believing in my team, in myself and in my game."
Carreno Busta became the first unseeded winner in Canada in two decades.
Poland's Hurkacz had been unbeaten in five finals, Carreno Busta putting the first blemish on that record in just over an hour and three quarters.
He survived 18 aces from Hurkacz to become the first Canadian champion ranked outside the Top 20 since number 43 Andrei Pavel in 2001 at Montreal.
Carreno Busta is the third Spanish winner after five-time champion Rafael Nadal and Manuel Orantes in 1975.
The first two sets were mirror images with Hurkacz breaking in the sixth game on his way to winning the opener.
In the second Carreno Busta, who is projected to rise to 14th in the world, claimed a break in the second game and held his margin to leave the match hanging at one set each.
Two breaks in the final set sealed the win for Carreno Busta, who wrapped it up on his first match point as he broke Hurkacz for the win.
"I lost the first set, just one break, but you know when you play against these kinds of players who have a really good serve it's really tough to be there," Carreno Busta said.
"But I just continued believing because I know that I was playing better and better. I tried to be aggressive with my serves and I could make two breaks, enough to be a winner."
Hurkacz said it was a deserved victory.
"Pablo was playing really, really well throughout the whole match," Hurkacz said. "It just was tough to play against him.
"Maybe I wasn't serving as good as I can. But definitely Pablo deserved to win today."
He added: "It's definitely a good week, (I made) a lot of improvements. "I'll learn a lot from that week and move on to the next one."
Summary: Pablo Carreno Busta seized his first ATP Masters title Sunday, spoiling Hubert Hurkacz's perfect record in ATP finals with a Montreal Masters triumph.
Author: Tram Lines

Title: A Pandemic Pivot Gives Rise to New F&B Future
Text:
Founded in 1998 in Los Angeles by Avi Brosh, Palisociety is a fully integrated hospitality company that acquires, designs, develops, owns and operates unique hotels and residences across the country under three distinct monikers: Palihouse, Palihotel, ARRIVE by Palisociety and a collection of independently branded properties.
Our proprietary brands, development and operational expertise also includes specialized retail spaces and highly curated restaurants, bars and event venues. Palisociety properties have been featured on Conde Nast Traveler's Hot List, Travel + Leisure's IT List, and more, with accolades from the New York Times, Architectural Digest, Wallpaper* and countless others.
Brosh's proprietor-driven vision of hospitality takes its roots from the innkeepers of days past. Where the owner not only held the keys to a hotel, but held the entirety of its experience, in his creative and physical hands. He believes in treating each hotel like its own neighborhood focal point and works from there to curate, design and develop an experience that is not only highly personalized to the city it calls home, but to his unique impression of luxury hospitality – one rooted in community, comfort, inspiration and a very hands-on approach to every facet and detail.
When the pandemic took hold of the hospitality industry, it impacted our business at Palisociety from so many perspectives that seemingly unfolded one after the other…after the other. As an independent brand focused on small-key properties around the country, our first course of action was to keep our business and employees afloat while we kept up with the industry's ever-evolving demand, setbacks, and income insecurities. It felt like every day brought forth a new challenge, whether it was with travel demand, staffing, supply chain issues, or general lack of confidence about the state of the industry and the world far beyond it. We worked to stay afloat, thinking ahead with every new step and first and foremost, setting the business up for survival.
Our next course of action was to stabilize. While the world espoused the term "new normal," we took it very personally. We knew that things were shifting in a sense that would impact not only the current state of our business, but the future of it. And we saw that need for stabilization expand beyond the hotel business into the food & beverage entities, which has led the path forward for Palisociety in more ways than one.
The coastal Italian menu at Marco Polo Trattoria and Bar, at home in Palisociety's Silver Lake Pool & Inn
In early 2020, we operated 12 hotels and seven restaurant concepts. They included signature coffee shops and all-day restaurants. French bistro fare and Southern classics. Large dining rooms, bars, intimate cafes, and more. In the year that followed, we opened two more hotels (with three more F&B offerings) and took ownership of ARRIVE Hotels & Restaurants, which included four properties, each with their own F&B models for a total of 10 additional concepts in the portfolio.
Many of our restaurants were not open on the same schedule. Some served dinner, some didn't. Others offered weekend brunch, while some did not. Breakfast was a mainstay, but it didn't operate with the same model in Seattle versus Miami; Austin versus San Francisco. One thing was consistent, however: the incredible impact of COVID-19. Most of our restaurants were forced to close, re-open and then close again. We routinely had to scramble to keep up with local and regional restrictions and fluctuating service parameters in markets across the country. Long-term and new employees were relocating at a rapid pace.
And most critically, we knew that we weren't going back to the way it was before.
The dining room at ARRIVE Wilmington's, Dram Yard.
So, we set forth on a new path. As the world emerged back into restaurants and cafes in 2021, a gap in demand further separated quality restaurants from the rest of the pack, yielding peak profits for some and closure for others. We knew we wanted to be the former. And with such, this summer we will debut the Palisociety Dining Group. It is a new segment of the business, built exclusively to focus on our food & beverage programming, operations, and management, across our portfolio. It will allow us to consolidate our offerings and to focus our efforts in a streamlined direction that not only enables us to secure the business as the changing tides of the pandemic's impact continue to fluctuate, but empowers us to grow this side of our business from both a culinary and revenue point of view.
The problems in the industry are not going away. Wage pressures are not subsiding, and we are in an environment where your restaurant staff is inevitably going to be more transient than before the pandemic, regardless of the size of your operation. So, we are working to standardize as much of the F&B business as possible in terms of menu creation, service, and offerings. To create a more uniform approach that will become the standard across all our properties and venues, with room for creativity and in-market personality, of course, but with a scalable, standardized template that will live independently, but in careful cohesion with the hotel business. We want to ensure our staff is prepared. We want them to have all the tools and systems in place to ensure success, not only from the guest's point of view, but from their point of view.
A Los Angeles favorite, the outdoor dining room at Silver Lake Pool & Inn's Marco Polo Trattoria and Bar
When you create a set of SOPs, recipes or training edicts that are already established, vetted and poised for success, across the brand, we believe it helps to empower the people bringing them to life. Which leads to better employee relations, consistency in staffing and hopefully, an overall better experience from all facets. We not only want to retain employees, we want to retain happy employees. Ones who feel supported, inspired and driven to work within a brand family that has stability and security top of mind, alongside all the creative, fun elements of our business. Of which there are so many.
Thus, we saw the opportunity to perfect the concept of the "neighborhood hotel restaurant" by investing in a team of talented chefs, visionaries, and operators who would help us bring this new vision to life, and by leveraging the robust operations and infrastructure of our existing hotel platform to create efficiencies and standardization across multiple unique and intimate food & beverage outlets. With our new F&B model, the Palisociety Dining Group, we will be focusing on creating and developing four key concepts across the portfolio (Italian, French, All-Day and Mediterranean), versus several.
We will work with incredible culinary talents who know how to bring these flavors and profiles to life with an eye for quality and efficiency. An eye that only comes from years of experience in the restaurant world. We will continue to operate and develop specialty concepts in certain markets, but the standardization of our F&B concepts across the board will give us the ability to execute with consistency and operational excellence. In marrying our creative food and beverage talents with our hospitality processes and effectiveness, our focus is on creating consistency and reliability across the platform and within every hotel, from coast to coast.
A feast for all the senses at ARRIVE Wilmington's Dram Yard
Portfolio wide, today, we operate 17 food and beverage outlets with several new venues in the works. In late 2022, we will be adding four new venues across three new hotels and in 2023, we will be adding an additional 10 venues across nine new hotels. The underlying success of Palisociety Dining Group food and beverage outlets will stem from the importance we place on our restaurants being unique outposts for the platform in each neighborhood we inhabit, yet with an underlying framework of structure, repetition, and consistency. We believe great service and great food never goes out of style and that it's always 5 o'clock somewhere. Our menus are seasonal, our cocktails are impeccably crafted, and our price points are moderate. That will be reflected across every space and with every menu.
For example, our interpretation of Southern Californian cuisine is all about fresh, local ingredients, prepared simply, but with a playful spirit that is inspired by the region's abundance of agricultural and culinary diversity, from the border of Mexico to the mountains and the farms in the north. Palisociety's new All-Day Menu celebrates the best of West Coast dining combining iconic hotel menu standards such as a classic American breakfast and soon-to-be Palisociety classics like the Palicobb Salad. Equal parts fresh and familiar, every bite is bright, satisfying, and worthy of repeat visits and it will be featured in Palihouse Santa Barbara, Palihouse Santa Monica and ARRIVE Palm Springs simultaneously as one of the debut offerings from Palisociety Dining Group. The French, Italian and Mediterranean concepts will follow suit with one principal all-day menu being offered across the venues that speak to that f&b vision with consistency across the board.
The future in F&B is bright, but not without some creative thinking, investments in training, culture and consistency, and an eye for not only what is now, but what is next. The pandemic stole many things from our industry, but it's offered us this opportunity as well. And it's one we plan to relish. No pun intended.
Main Image: An inside look at Simonette, a charming French bistro inside Palihotel Culver City
Mr. Von Stiening
Jorgan von Stiening is the president of Palisociety, a vertically integrated Los Angeles based independent hospitality enterprise, which designs, owns and operates a national portfolio of hotels and restaurants under five distinct hotel brands: Palihouse, Palihotel, ARRIVE by Palisociety, Le Petit Pali, and the Palisociety Independent. Joining Palisociety in 2018, Mr. von Stiening leads the brand's national platform of hotels with over 1,000 employees across the country. He is responsible for executing the company's operations, growth strategies and oversees its financial performance. Originally from New York, he received his undergraduate degree in Business Administration and Accounting from Binghamton University. He spent his early career advising on US and Caribbean hotel transactions and developments at EY (Ernst & Young), where he worked in their New York and Miami offices. In 2018, he relocated to Los Angeles with his husband and dog to join the Palisociety team.
Extended Biography & Contact Information

Summary: By Jorgan Von Stiening President, Palisociety | August 14, 2022

Title: Combating The Food & Beverage Industry Labor Shortage
Text:
The world has suffered greatly over the past two years. From the COVID-19 pandemic to tense foreign affairs, families, communities and industries across the globe are reeling as we emerge from prevailing crisis.
In the food and beverage industry specifically, bar and restaurant owners have navigated shutdowns that, in some cases, completely halted business.
Exercising creativity and business prowess, owners have implemented new policies and procedures designed to promote the health and safety of employees and customers, while also pivoting business models.
Moving from dine-in to take out, from packing establishments with customers to encouraging social distancing and from curating new menus to navigating supply chain shortages, bar and restaurant owners and operators have given their all to support the brands they represent.
Now, as food and beverage concepts begin to get back on their feet, a new crisis has emerged: a global labor shortage. Though the specific driving factor behind the labor shortage is unclear, it has forced bar and restaurant owners to, once again, reevaluate their business model, as well as their approach to recruitment and employee retention.
In the United States alone, Valor Hospitality Partners currently represents 22 hotel properties, 17 of which have dedicated food and beverage concepts. Drawing inspiration from global partners and a dedicated food and beverage team, our team at Valor has identified key learnings while navigating the labor shortage.
Employees Are Holding the Cards
A departure from employment history, the current employment landscape shows that candidates are largely in control throughout the recruitment process, and even into the role itself. As food and beverage concepts nationwide scramble to find qualified candidates to fill open roles, the market has shifted from employers sifting through a pool of qualified candidates to one dictated by the candidates themselves.
This trend has led to a rise in labor costs, and, ultimately, an increase in cost for the consumer as well. Coupled with a disruption in the global supply chain, bars and restaurants are navigating operating costs at a record high.
Alongside employees seeking higher wages, many bars and restaurants are demanding longer working hours and greater crossover in responsibilities. In many cases, these circumstances are inspiring a departure from the hospitality industry as a whole, as many roles are reliant on gratuities to supplement income.
So how does a restaurant concept attract top talent? It's all in how you sell it.
Recruitment Strategies Have Changed
With employees in charge, bars and restaurants have been tasked with expanding their recruitment strategies. In the current landscape, there are several digital tools available to assist with recruitment efforts. From apps to help fill short-term needs to a wealth of online job boards, the difference between one restaurant and another can boil down to details as minute as the look of the ad itself.
Be thorough with your job descriptions. Be positive with what your specific brand can offer candidates. Allocate advertising dollars to help maximize your reach. These practices (and more) can help set one concept apart from another. Additionally, partnering with professional recruiters, or even bringing professionals in-house, is a great way to maximize efforts and attract top talent in a given area.
Despite the current landscape being employee-driven, hiring teams should remain mindful of the qualities that are important to look out for in each individual role. For those entering the hospitality industry, Valor seeks candidates who are career-minded and eager to learn and grow. For senior-level roles, Valor seeks candidates who are tenacious, loyal and team-driven.
Ultimately, thorough recruitment efforts may drive new hires, but creating and maintaining a positive culture is paramount to retaining high quality talent.
Differentiating Your Business
Valor Hospitality has the unique ability to oversee the creation of bar and restaurant concepts, requesting a seat at the table during even the earliest stages of development. This leads to ensuring the concept itself is a perfect fit for each respective property. Our concepts have the "cool" factor, and we know it.
Thoughtfully designed concepts are a differentiator for Valor properties, which often positively influence recruitment efforts. Identifying the unique qualities of any bar or restaurant and bringing that differentiator to the forefront will help attract talent best suited for any open role.
Highlight any perks that accompany your establishment, giving a "why" for candidates who are inundated with options. Do you offer competitive benefits? Is the restaurant itself a celebrity hotspot? Are the operating hours noteworthy? Is there opportunity for additional training or career advancement?
While establishment-specific distinctions are important to highlight, the hospitality industry as a whole has a wide range of positive qualities that have been overshadowed by recent events.
Differentiating Your Industry
A career in hospitality offers endless opportunities for professional growth. On a granular level, front--of-house roles like hosting, serving or bartending help develop customer service and problem-solving skills in a fast-paced setting, which serve as a jumping off point for those seeking expanded careers in hospitality or similar industries.
Opportunities in a culinary career are vast, with many aspiring chefs learning the trade from a young age and excelling into careers as an executive chef or director of food and beverage. For those seeking a career in leadership, the hospitality industry offers a range of advancement options in individual restaurant concepts, hospitality group leadership and even entrepreneurship and ownership.
Ultimately, a career in the food and beverage industry is a career in a skilled trade, arming employees with tools and resources to excel throughout their entire professional life.
The Importance of Company Culture
Perhaps the most important pillar of business is a healthy company culture. In recent months, burnout has been rampant across the globe, and businesses have been tasked with combating feelings of burnout while also navigating labor shortages.
A pillar of Valor's success throughout the pandemic and beyond is rooted in its commitment to culture. Across departments, dynamic leadership lays the groundwork for the health of all teams. In food and beverage specifically, leadership is the foundation for a positive culture.
Beginning with a dedicated corporate team, Valor builds strong leadership structures into each of its individual hotel and restaurant concepts. From the CEO to the restaurant floor, our leaders are expected to integrate with their teams, lead by example and always remain open to employee feedback.
Employee engagement is another important focus for Valor's food and beverage teams. Are the employees happy? Do they have everything they need? Do they feel comfortable asking questions and raising concerns? Are their personal and professional goals being met?
Approaching relationships between employees and leadership as mutually beneficial will help promote a positive culture and, ultimately, help retain quality employees.
Tackling Turnover During Crisis
Once quality employees are on the roster, how do bars and restaurants prevent turnover? Beyond company culture, that answer lies in training and development.
Providing quality training reemphasizes a company's commitment to its people. Whether through robust programs to help employees become experts in a specific role or by providing opportunities for team members to explore career advancement, offering thorough training and development initiatives incentivizes employees to remain on the team.
Valor recently launched its Future Leaders program in the United States, offering an opportunity for continuing education and leadership training across company roles. For example, if a food and beverage director is interested in learning about operations or revenue management, Valor provides an 18-month program to help employees hit that goal. Already seeing success throughout Valor's U.K. portfolio, this program will continue to be rolled out throughout 2022 and beyond.
Ultimately, investing in training and development not only promotes a specific establishment, but the health of the hospitality industry as a whole.
Remembering the Customer
Hospitality is, at its core, a people business. One of the most challenging aspects of the labor shortage is the impact the crisis has had on quality customer service. In an attempt to manage expectations, signage warning consumers about reduced staff, increased pricing and slower service are appearing in storefronts nationwide.
With reduced staff across the board, hoteliers and restaurateurs are tasked with maintaining standards of service while also navigating an unprecedented labor and supply chain crisis. With customer service top of mind, engagement remains a priority at all levels.
This means leadership needs to be on the floor, communicating with customers and owning tasks outside their job description. Customer-facing roles require expanded training to navigate challenging situations. The culinary team needs to communicate thoroughly and effectively to ensure food service doesn't waver.
Overcoming most labor shortage challenges are rooted in engagement. Customers need engagement to feel served, employees need engagement to feel supported and candidates need engagement to feel prioritized.
By integrating initiatives to develop, engage and prioritize employees, the hospitality industry as a whole is sure to emerge from this crisis stronger than ever.
Mr. Martha
As Global Director of Food & Beverage, Chris Martha directs and oversees all aspects of each Valor Hospitality food and beverage concept, including the organization, concept and menu planning, design, preparation and presentation of food and drinks, and adherence to quality and safety standards. With an extensive background in the food, beverage and overall hospitality experience, Mr. Martha has perfected the balance between driving operational efficiencies without compromising the overall experience and satisfaction of his guests, an attribute that serves at Valor food and beverage concepts well. His career began with an internship with Hyatt Regency Resorts in Hilton Head, SC, which led to a permanent position at the hotel's location in Beaver Creek, CO. Hyatt proved to be an excellent training ground, but his heart was in smaller, independent eateries. Mr. Martha moved to Atlanta during the tourism surge brought on by the 1996 Olympic games and spent seven years with Fifth Group Restaurants, including Atlanta favorites such as South City Kitchen, LaTavola and the Food Studio.

Summary: By Chris Martha Global Director of Food & Beverage, Valor Hospitality Partners | August 14, 2022

Title: Food and Beverage Lessons in a Post-Pandemic Hotel Industry
Text:
It's a massive understatement to say the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted food and beverage operations in hotels worldwide.
Restaurants closed or slashed capacity, QR codes replaced physical menus and to-go options became a necessity for all properties. Virtual events replaced in-person dining activations and face-to-face time with guests was strictly limited.
Travelers who have returned to Hawaii since the reopening of tourism are looking for an escape following this difficult period. The first guests back to Wailea Beach Resort were looking to relive their pre-COVID experiences and we were able to give them a bit of this, with limited restaurant openings and scaled-back offerings. We're now entering a brand-new moment within this industry in which we're seeing skyrocketing demand for our offerings in a post-restriction tourism environment that allows for full dining rooms and expanded guest numbers. All Wailea Beach Resort's dining venues, including its signature restaurant, Humble Market Kitchin, helmed by Celebrity Chef Roy Yamaguchi, KAPA Bar and Grill, Whale's Tale coffee house, Mo'Bettah food truck, two bars and more, are now seeing full houses and a plethora of eager customers.
A great amount of learning is done under stress and the hotel food and beverage industry was under an immense amount of pressure to deliver quality experiences within stringent health and safety guidelines. The lessons I and other industry veterans take away from this period of history will usher in a new era of hospitality in order to meet the needs of the 2022 traveler.
Wailea Beach Resort's NALU Pool
Individualized Dining Experiences
Personalized dining experiences were already part of our expansive offerings at Wailea Beach Resort pre-pandemic, and the need for socially distanced vacations during the pandemic made the desire for intimate offerings apparent. Now, restrictions have loosened but guests remain hungry for private meals. Consequently, it's now all about bringing these individualized experiences up to a grander scale – one that allows guests the opportunity to have a secluded private dining experience for two that feels a world away from the bustling resort.
Currently, Wailea Beach Resort offers various oceanfront dining venues on the beach and a floating cabana candlelight dining experience atop one of the property's pools, all of which feature the service of a personal attendant. Since I arrived at the resort, all three settings have been coveted bookings requiring over a month's notice to secure the most desired days and times. These often take the form of date nights, proposals, anniversaries, birthday festivities or simply celebrations of a return to travel.
We also have formed a partnership with local business Maui Luxe Picnics to allow guests to book another version of the private dining experience. These picnics are complete with romantic lighting, rugs/blankets, pillow cushions, fresh flowers and gourmet grazing platters, and have been immensely popular with those looking for a truly unique private meal on-property.
The biggest takeaway, as Wailea Beach Resort continues to hone in on private offerings, is that while we must always focus our dining services on meeting the needs of the guest population as a collective, it's now essential that we enhance our service at the customized level as well. Guests want the absolute best experiences that feature local ingredients, are served by the most talented culinary teams, and are executed by top notch luxury service experts, no matter the cost.
Due to increasing demand, private dining is being offered at record prices, and the constructive feedback we collect is not about price, but about asking the resort to offer more bookable options. This has afforded us the ability to create the exact atmospheres that guests look for and continue to elevate these experiences, as we are able to work the cost of materials, labor, etc. directly into the price.
I have been working closely with the resort's new executive chef, Amanda Lindquist, to continue to ideate expanded ways in which we can make a large property feel small for guests by allowing them to tailor their food and beverage experience to their specific desires.
Guests staying in the property's Sundeck Collection can bask in the sun when ordering in-room dining to their indoor/outdoor suite.
In-Room Dining Offerings
As an extension of the individualized dining experience, the pandemic heightened the popularity of in-room dining among travelers, with menus that offer something for everyone. We haven't seen enthusiasm for this convenient offering wane in the months following the reopening of travel. With the convenient Marriott Bonvoy app and The Hub, an interactive guest portal, Wailea Beach resort guests can post in-room dining charges to their room (as well as book dining reservations, activities, spa services and more) allowing for easy last-minute decisions and creating an avenue to offer additional customized experiences.
We are currently working on expanding the property's pre-arrival amenities, brainstorming ways in which we can incorporate Maui and Hawaii local business products and snacks into welcome packages and pairing these with an exciting selection of wines from Hawaii and beyond. The more interactive our offerings the better – we plan on including materials explaining how we built our packages and in-room activations, expanding our make-your-own cocktail kits and more. Current amenities available to guests include "Pau Hana" (Hawaii's version of Happy Hour) that comes with locally brewed craft beers from Maui Brewing Company, a DIY Mai Tai kit and "Pineapple Three Ways," a package that allows guests to sample local pineapple freshly-cut, dried and in cake pop form.
Guest and Staff Interaction
In a similar vein, while guests are responding well to individualized offerings, we are seeing a robust desire for person-to-person contact. The strongest responses we receive are from activations or services involving guest interactions, and rebuilding specialty touchpoints throughout the guest experience is now a main focus for the management team.
After over a year of limited personal interactions, Wailea Beach Resort guests want to talk and shake hands with those they meet on vacation, including our staff. Travelers to Hawaii are looking to learn and conversate during their trip and walk away with new connections and a deeper knowledge of the destination and its culture. While grab-and-go dining options reigned in the early stages of the pandemic (and remain important for guests on the go, an area of focus for our cafe Whale's Tale), a main area of expansion for the resort is now coming in the form of guest/staff relationships.
We're exploring ways for our resort chefs to cook live in front of guests, host educational culinary workshops and more to ultimately forge a meaningful and personal relationship with guests throughout their stay. Existing offerings such as our nightly fireside s'mores and Mo'olelo (Hawaiian storytelling) achieve this kind of bonding and it allows guests to both learn from staff and indulge in homey treats.
Our mission is to cultivate a strong dining presence in the Wailea Beach Resort experience, and to ensure that our hardworking, knowledgeable team members are as visible to guests as their delicious drinks and dishes. Already, menus throughout the entire resort feature thoughtful treats like Kiyo Miller's Famous Banana Bread – Kiyo is a Maui local, and long-time team member at Wailea Beach Resort – and reflect our desire to imbed our dining services with personal connections. It's important that our team members feel empowered and embraced as well - we've been lucky to not have had labor shortages up to this point and it is our goal to keep this trend going.
Local Vendors and Produce
The pandemic was a wake-up call for communities worldwide about the importance of local businesses and neighborhood support. Right now, only a small percentage of produce offered at other Hawaiian resorts is actually grown in Hawaii – imported goods make up a large portion of food consumed in the Hawaiian tourism sector. This is a missed opportunity to bolster other Hawaiian industries and takes away from the authenticity of the guest experience.
At Wailea Beach Resort, my team and I have committed to disrupting this longstanding pattern by embracing local produce, cooking techniques and products as much as possible - not just within the island of Maui but within Hawaii as a whole. This will be accomplished by cultivating relationships with producers on all the islands, allowing Wailea Beach Resort to source seasonal items from different parts of the state.
I am a firm believer that you can tell a lot about a culture through its cuisine. Many of my most impactful, treasured travel memories and most coveted vacation traditions are centered around food. I bring this mindset with me to my position at Wailea Beach Resort, and believe it is an important benefit to guests that we ensure our dishes reflect Hawaii's great offerings.
While our menus already contain local ingredients, we are looking to, in the end, fully convert all former imports to Hawaiian-grown produce. This will be a lengthy process for the resort, but we aim to work towards this goal by slowly infusing our menus with locally sourced produce and building to the point where we can highlight Maui and Hawaiian goods all the way to the banquet level as well.
The common thread weaving together our path forward is deeply rooted in connecting at a far more personal level with guests than we've seen in this industry before, and bringing this same commitment to building relationships to our vendors, staff and list of offerings. Sitting down for dinner is the most basic level of human connection and our jobs in food and beverage management require our preservation of this same attitude throughout our work.
Mr. Matsui
Eric Matsui is the Director of Food and Beverage at Wailea Beach Resort, where he oversees the property's dining operations. Mr. Matsui comes to Wailea Beach Resort with over two decades of experience, most recently serving as the Director of Food and Beverage at world-renowned Relais & Châteaux property Hotel Wailea, which brought him to his new home in Hawaii. Prior to that, he entered the world of hotels as restaurant general manager at Auberge Du Soleil, a Relais & Châteaux property with a Michelin starred restaurant, following stints as food and beverage operations manager at the San Jose Marriott and San Francisco's Renaissance Stanford Court Hotel on Nob Hill. Before this, Mr. Matsui had a decade-long career in restaurants at both hourly and managerial levels, starting as a server at 18 years old. Born and raised in San Francisco, he spent his younger years tasting dishes made by his grandfather, a restaurateur, and shadowing his uncle, an industry veteran with 50+ years of experience in hospitality management. He is thrilled to have made his way back to the Marriott family, to which he has a deep personal tie - a family member of his worked directly for Bill Marriott himself.

Title: Solutions That Promote Job Satisfaction and Elevate F&B Service Everywhere Your Guests Want to Be
Text:
Imagine you are a server at a busy resort. You arrive at work in a great mood, pick up a tablet, sign in, head outdoors, and then greet your first customer by name. You take their order, it goes directly to the kitchen, and food and drinks (F&B) are delivered quickly to your guest, without you leaving your service area and without them leaving their chair.
You develop a rapport with your guests, and you help them choose from additional food and beverage items throughout the day. At the end of your shift, your guests have had a great afternoon at the beach or pool, you had an enjoyable day at work, you received some sizable tips, and you both look forward to doing it again tomorrow.
Resorts have found technology solutions that help them breathe new life into their legacy point-of-sale (POS) systems and extend their F&B reach to guests wherever they want to be on property – far beyond the reach of Wi-Fi networks. Resorts like Pinehurst and Kohler are offering uninterrupted F&B service at the farthest reaches of their properties through 5G-enabled mobile POS technology, and their servers are reaping the benefits of these easy-to-use solutions, via happier guests and higher tips.
When you make an employee's job easier and provide them with more opportunities to increase their income, it directly impacts service levels, the guest experience, and ultimately, the employee's job satisfaction. Resorts with happy, well-treated, well-compensated servers and attendants don't have staffing problems. Technology that allows servers to access 5G networks plays an important role in helping guests enjoy more of their vacation time and spend less time waiting in lines and waiting for service. Employees are experiencing higher job satisfaction levels by using these solutions, and it translates directly to the guest. Happy servers mean happy guests, and happy guests mean happy servers. It comes full circle, and that's a chain that no property wants to break.
5G-enabled mobile F&B solutions are easy to use, remove the stress of walking back and forth from the kitchen, and allow staff members to enjoy more time with their guests.
What Employees Want
One of the biggest challenges all resort properties are facing is staffing shortages. So how do you hire and retain the best talent? Make their jobs easier and more enjoyable, ensure job satisfaction, and give them the ability to make more money. Guests shouldn't be the only ones having fun; if servers enjoy their jobs they can't help but provide great service.
Vice Media Group cited a job-related health study of more than 138,700 participants by Southern Medical University in Guangzhou, China. In this study, scientists concluded that it is more stressful to be a server than to be a neurosurgeon, and demanding jobs that offer little control like waiting tables can negatively affect mental and physical health. Unfortunately, since the pandemic – F&B service jobs have gotten more stressful due to smaller teams and guests expecting the same level of service they've experienced in the past.
F&B service is one job category that is at risk for musculoskeletal injuries from performing repetitive manual tasks. According to a research project by Jenny Craig referenced by Healthline Media, on average, servers take 22,778 steps per day compared to 16,390 for nurses, 14,660 for retail workers, 14,037 for farmers, and 7,570 for office workers. That's a lot of steps, and a lot of time away from their guests.
In his book, "Restaurant Success by the Numbers," restaurant owner and consultant Roger Fields said, "The farther away dining areas are from the kitchen and service stations, the more fatigued your servers will become during the course of a busy shift, and the less likely to provide good service…The ease with which your staff can accomplish their tasks will enhance the diner's experience and make your staff's jobs considerably easier."
That's where technology comes in. Solutions that allow servers to spend more time with their customers and less time running back and forth between their section and a fixed terminal reduce wear and tear on their bodies – plus, they enjoy their jobs more. Using 5G-enabled mobile F&B solutions built for the outdoors, servers can go where the guest is and provide a positive experience for them both – through increased speed of service from order to delivery. When resort properties provide team members with tools that make their jobs easier, more enjoyable, and more lucrative, it's a win-win-win for the property, its employees, and its guests.
With wireless, guests can order F&B in remote areas like the golf course and choose from a variety of flexible payment options.
What Guests Want
Resorts must find ways to keep up with changing guest demands, and they need to do so with fewer resources than ever. Today's guests want to be able to order and pay for a drink or snack wherever they are on property and not have to wait an unreasonable amount of time for that snack or drink to arrive. Giving servers the tools to stay in their section leads to more frequent check-ins with guests. An available server makes the decision for another round easy, resulting in higher average checks and higher tips.
Deloitte's report, "The Restaurant of the Future: A Vision Evolves," found that 68 percent of respondents do not want to wait more than 30 minutes to receive their food orders. When resort guests are stretched out across expansive outdoor event venues, pool decks, beaches and golf courses, they would normally have to interrupt their fun to wait in a line or flag down a server. With solutions like 5G-enabled mobile POS, service comes to them, and they can keep having fun wherever they are on the resort.
As Jean Chick, principal, Deloitte Consulting LLP, and U.S. restaurant and food service leader added to the report, "The pandemic has accelerated the progress of the restaurant of the future, calling for fundamental shifts in business models to meet new demands. Those that can quickly adapt and meet diners' evolving demands for convenience, frictionless digital experiences and safety can be poised to not only survive but thrive." Solutions that allow guests to be outside, anywhere on property, enjoying their vacation, are what guests want and what hotels need.
What Resorts Need to Keep Both Employees and Guests Happy
To elevate service and increase revenue, resort properties must attract and retain the best of the best talent to ensure a positive guest experience. Successful properties are enhancing their existing systems with 5G mobile POS solutions that help make server's jobs easier and more enjoyable, and enable them to provide seamless service wherever their guests are – out having fun at the far reaches of the property.
Resort properties need mobile technology solutions that go beyond traditional Wi-Fi networks, work seamlessly with their existing systems, and make an immediate impact on both the employee and guest experience. Even in most remote areas of the property – the beach, the pool, the golf course – that typically pose connection challenges, attendants can create a check for guests, and accept payment with a credit card, tap-to-pay, room charge or cash. Staff can set up satellite F&B outlets in outdoor event spaces or concert venues without the need for fixed terminals and without relying on spotty internet service. Employees can easily move around these outdoor areas and offer F&B service using lightweight, sunlight-friendly tablets, allowing them to focus more time on their guests and drastically improve speed of service.
Technology shouldn't create more work for the property; it should make operations easier and more efficient – ideally while increasing revenue. In addition to providing seamless service to guests all over your property, today's F&B solutions can also automate payroll, tips and scheduling – all without tedious manual entry by the management team. They offer secure payment processing, and they limit loss prevention by extending service to areas beyond the Wi-Fi network for quick and easy card approval. Solutions that are enabled by 5G technology and are built for movement, allow resort properties to sell more F&B items to more guests in more areas than ever before – and that means better service for guests, higher earnings for employees and more revenue for the property.
Today, resorts can offer uninterrupted F&B service in outdoor event areas without the need for fixed terminals, and beyond the limitations of the property's Wi-Fi network.
Happy Servers = Happy Guests
While many hotel properties are trying to recover lost F&B revenue, others are gaining in revenue this year and creating new revenue streams just by deploying 5G-enabled solutions that are built for the outdoors. The savviest of hoteliers are enabling a much faster speed of service to a far wider area, capturing significantly more revenue, and keeping the best team members as tips increase dramatically.
Happy servers, with the tools they need to provide an exceptional experience, equal happy guests. It's really that simple. When resort properties focus on job satisfaction for their team members, they see a direct correlation to elevated guest service, resulting in more generous tips for their team and more positive reviews for their property.
Guests are ready to travel again and enjoy all the activities your property has to offer, and they have their wallets open. Your team needs to go where the guest wants to be in order to better serve them and capture more of their spend. With 5G-enabled mobile POS solutions, a server is nearby and available whenever the guest is ready for service. Bring the service to the guest at your most desirable outdoor spaces and you are providing an exceptional experience. Give the guest a reason to reward you with increased spend, their server with a generous tip, and your property with a positive review. You'll welcome them back again and again.
Mr. Stange
David Stange is the Founder and Chief Innovation Officer of Beachy. In 2015, Mr. Stange launched Beachy to address the limitations of beachfront, pool, golf course and open-air venue commerce and logistics. The company developed and patented geospatial technology that maps a resort's beach or pool deck and allow guests to reserve their deck chairs, cabanas, jet ski's etc. online at the time of their hotel reservation. Beachy also developed the Beachy Attendant Booking solution to make guest amenity check in fast and accurate; and the Beachy Admin Portal which allows a resort to easily manage their unique Beachy implementation. In 2021, Beachy introduced Beachy Food & Beverage. A 5G cellular-supported mobile point-of-sale solution, with tight integration to leading fixed POS terminals, allowing fast, reliable guest service at the farthest reaches of a resort's beaches, pool decks, golf courses and open-air event venues. Mr. Stange has been recognized as one of Nashville's 40 under 40 and served as the youngest recipient of the award at 28. He earned his bachelor's degree from the University of Alabama and lives in Destin Florida with his wife and two kids.

Summary: By David Stange Founder & Chief Innovation Officer, Beachy | August 14, 2022

Title: Elevating The Alpine Aesthetic
Text:
While the traditional mountain lodge aesthetic can appeal to travelers' escapist mentality with old world charm, mountain hotels and resorts are embracing modern design elements and creating comfortable spaces that pay homage to their surroundings with a nuanced, less heavy-handed style.
Pent up demand for outdoor adventures and mountain escapes is strong, and resorts and hotels – especially those near national parks – have an opportunity to create unique expressions of mountain living that resonate with today's discerning travelers.
After a day of exploring the outdoors, escaping to a luxurious mountain retreat where multifaceted patterns, textures, and materials engage the senses and create long-lasting memories will encourage guests to book longer stays and make repeat visits to the private clubs and resort destinations that offer such experiences.
Created with a sophisticated, modern barn-inspired aesthetic, the specialty restaurant at Yellowstone Club features finishes inspired by Montana's historic agricultural structures, with weathered wood planks on the walls and ceilings, hammered steel plates, seeded glass on light fixtures, and stone quarried in Montana. Image Credit: Peter and Kelley Gibeon, Gibeon Photography.
Carving Out Fresh Mountain Concepts Amidst The Rugged Landscape of Big Sky
Big Sky, Montana has long drawn travelers seeking tranquility amidst big, open spaces, and Rocky Mountain adventures to enjoy year-round, from fly-fishing, mountain biking, and hiking to skiing and snowshoeing. With the opening of Montage Big Sky, the destination's first luxury resort, the thrills of the great outdoors and refinement come together in a design that offers a contemporary take on the classic North American national park lodge. Right at their doorstep, guests and residents can find ski-in/ski-out access to 5,850 acres of world-class terrain and other outdoor amenities.
Situated less than an hour from Yellowstone National Park and surrounded by the awe-inspiring Spanish Peaks mountain range, the resort delivers a fresh expression of modern mountain luxury that welcomes travelers to Montana and the national park. The grandeur of the surrounding landscape and Big Sky history inspired the design of Montage Big Sky's 139 guestrooms, suites, and residences along with a range of on-site resort amenities, including a signature restaurant, cafe, lobby bar and lounge, gastro pub, poolside bar and outdoor grill, signature Spa Montage, fitness center, indoor pool, four bowling lanes, and a game room.
Located just northwest of Yellowstone National Park, Yellowstone Club has been an iconic destination in Big Sky Montana since its opening in 1997. A major expansion augmenting the heart of Yellowstone Club, the Village Core introduced an additional 555,000-square-feet of ultra-luxury residences and ski facilities, along with unique member amenities supporting spa experiences, fitness, dining, shopping, and community gathering. The new Village Core includes Buffalo Bar and Grill (BBG) restaurant, The Boot Room underground bar, a sales center, locker room, Yellowstone Club spa, and specialty restaurant BāBā, which brings premier Asian-inspired cuisine to the center of the Village Core with a striking octagonal structure wrapped in glass and lit beautifully from within.
Both Montage Big Sky and Yellowstone Club channel the multifaceted history of Big Sky and its stunning natural surroundings in their design. Let's take a closer look at the techniques behind each to explore different approaches to elevating the alpine aesthetic.
Contributing a sense of rustic luxury and coziness to the experience, furniture at Yellowstone Club's Buffalo Bar & Grille has a simple shape and solid look, being composed of heavy or thick raw woods with soft leathers and soft simple pattern fabrics. [Image Credit: Peter and Kelley Gibeon, Gibeon Photography]
Evoking a Sense of Place With a Palette of Timeless Materials
The interiors at Montage Big Sky feature regional wood and stones to ground users in the distinctive locale and evoke the genuine spirit of Big Sky. Drawing from iconic elements from Montana's old economy – from mining, timber, agriculture, and ranching – the design embraces the contemporary and reflects the new economy that is taking shape from changes in tourism, real estate, construction, and recreation in Montana. Public spaces feature the contemporary use of local stone, timber, and metal.
The hardware in guestroom bathrooms has a black finish like you might see in a blacksmith shop, and the stone on the counters is variegated, with a finish that gives a raw-edge appearance, as if it were cut from a mountain. Guestrooms and suites showcase rustic hues and a neutral palette accented by pops of color in small details. Rather than relying heavily on bold, dark colors that you might see in traditional mountain-style lodging, neutral colors help to reveal the natural textures of materials and imbue spaces with authenticity.
At Yellowstone Club's Buffalo Bar & Grille, the design draws inspiration from the landscape's rugged aesthetic, and materials are leveraged in their raw, natural state in an artful and engaging manner. The spaces feel casual and comfortable and can transform their ambience from day to night and from season to season, honoring Yellowstone Club as a year-round destination. All details have a hand-constructed quality that reflects the regional craftsmanship and history.
Elevating the alpine aesthetic does not necessarily mean doing away with rustic elements altogether. At Montage Big Sky, fabrics, leathers, and hammered metals take cues from Montana's strong western ranching traditions and natural textures that can be found at Yellowstone National Park. From inset leather and stitch detailing within metal mirrors to a chandelier pendant with branch-like features, the rustic touches deliver a modern take on the national park lodge theme. By working with loosely translated concepts - such as the restaurant chandeliers at Montage Big Sky, which feature four wagon wheels and cowbell-like shapes inspired by metalworkers in the region – mountain modern design can give subtle nods to history while exuding understated luxury.
In the lobby bar at Montage Big Sky, an all-black, metal fireplace with seating on both sides emerges from the ceiling in the center of the room, surprising and delighting guests with a contemporary take on a traditional fireplace. Image Credit: Christian Horan Photography.
Infusing References to Historical Architecture and Structures
The design of Montage Big Sky carries traces of the past but imbues spaces with elegant reinterpretations of historical influences. The Living Room at Montage Big Sky melds the past and present by featuring a contemporary take on a traditional fireplace. The floor-to-ceiling fireplaces bookend the Living Room and are positioned like you might see wood timber horizontally stacked in a log cabin style. However, in a contemporary twist, instead of wood, the fireplaces feature horizontally stacked stone. The leathered stone is precise and linear and laid in slabs in a way that harkens to the traditional log cabin aesthetic.
At Yellowstone Club, the new signature restaurant, BāBā by Ming Tsai, features an elegant, inviting atmosphere inspired by the historic barn, school, and ranch house structures of Montana's past.
Located at the heart of Yellowstone Club's Village Core, the octagonally-shaped dining room boasts 360-degree views of the scenic Rocky Mountains of Big Sky, Montana, and draws attention through its central location, distinctive shape and glass walls, and interior lighting. Honoring the overall aesthetic of the Village Core, which has a modern feel with rustic edges, BaBa features finishes such as weathered wood and hammered steel plates to gesture toward historic agricultural structures. In a nod to the state's historic lumber and timber industries, Douglas Fir timbers act as grand supporting beams that emphasize the octagonal shape of the ceiling.
While BaBa draws inspiration from historic barn structures in Montana, the bar at Yellowstone Club's Village Core is fashioned as an old mine, where high ceilings are supported by reclaimed wood planks and adorned with light fixtures resembling old oil lamps. The intimate, comfortable space is embellished with reclaimed vintage furniture and antique decorations, as well as vintage neon signs to light up the space.
The spa at Yellowstone Club honors the rich geophysical landscape of one of the most beautiful mountain terrains in the world and the rich Native American culture that characterizes the state of Montana and its surroundings. Image Credit: Peter and Kelley Gibeon, Gibeon Photography.
Bringing The "Great Outdoors" Inside
Mountain modern architecture often features clean lines, open layouts, and tall ceilings to maximize views and let the natural surroundings shine. Both Montage Big Sky and Yellowstone Club were designed with inspiration drawn from the grandeur of their surrounding landscape, and they illustrate useful techniques for achieving a modern mountain concept that brings the outdoors in.
With thoughtful use of materials, proportion, color, and light, the mountain modern design at Montage Big Sky delivers a cozy, luxurious setting whose shifting volumes frame the surrounding landscape.
The living room right off the main lobby at Montage Big Sky features large windows to showcase stunning mountain views. Double-height spaces with soaring gables in the ballroom, living room, and lobby bar embody the iconic Spanish Peaks that you see on the horizon line.
From an FF&E standpoint, Montage Big Sky connects guests to the surrounding region with an elegant outdoor theme expressed in patterns, textures, and materials. The carpet concepts draw from geological topographical maps and nature, and the color palette reflects natural hues that are prevalent in that part of the country. The custom area rug in the living room off the main lobby references clouds and the sky through moody greys and blues, and earthy crème tones. The reception area rug features a palette of dark, neutral, baked brown with greys and sandy undertones, with a carpet pattern on the grand stair that harkens to tree bark. In the lobby bar and lounge, greens and blues in the fabrics and finishes subtly reinforce the verdant woods and rivers near Big Sky.
The design of Spa Montage Big Sky creates a geometric interpretation of walking into a grotto or cave with origami-influenced walls that are faceted, bright, and unexpected. Surfaces appear like rocks that have been abstracted and sliced from a boulder. Angled millwork and cove lighting contribute a sense of calm and reflect a unique interpretation of the organic beauty of nature that draws so many to the rivers, trails, valleys, and mountainous landscapes of Big Sky.
In addition to honoring nature, The Yellowstone Club spa honors Montana's rich Native American culture with artwork, luscious earth tones, natural, textured materials and finishes, and neutral-toned, sculptural furniture inspired by the Montana landscape. As you move through various organically-shaped rooms, the feeling is akin to taking part in a ritual in which one reconnects with the earth. Soft lighting creates a calm, soothing spa atmosphere where guests can unwind and rejuvenate after a long day on the slopes or on the golf course.
COVID-19 has increased people's desire to feel regenerated amidst the beauty of nature, with more travelers eager to visit wide-open spaces and experience unique hotels in picturesque mountain settings. There is great opportunity in thoughtfully designing hotels that cater to an audience seeking a luxe experience after a long day exploring the outdoors. However, people's palates have changed, and they crave multi-faceted experiences and more textured, nuanced environments that make their stays more memorable. Elevating the alpine aesthetic with special attention to a site's history and landscape will make an impact without guests even realizing how or why, but the thoughtful, artistically executed design will be hard to forget.
Main Image: Inspired by Big Sky history and the beauty and grandeur of its natural surroundings, including the majestic Spanish Peaks mountain range, Montage Big Sky features large timbers, hammered steel, stone and wood floors, and color palettes organized, finished, and placed in a contemporary fashion in grand volumes. Image Credit: Christian Horan Photography.
Ms. Fischbach
Growing up in the colorful city of Los Angeles, Rachel Fischbach's passion for the arts developed at a young age. Inspired by her grandmother, who introduced her to the world of art and design, Ms. Fischbach gravitated toward hospitality interior design as it combines her love of travel and art. Since joining BraytonHughes Design Studios in 2001, Ms. Fischbach has been involved in all phases of the design process, providing creative and innovative design solutions for a variety of hospitality, restaurant, and private club projects. Her professional career includes over fifteen years of experience specializing in luxury hotel design domestically and internationally. Ms. Fischbach is proud of her recent work on the Village Core at the Yellowstone Club and Montage Big Sky resort and residences in Big Sky, Montana. In addition to providing excellent service to clients while delivering outstanding design quality, Ms. Fischbach oversees the company's marketing efforts alongside BraytonHughes Design Studios Principal, Kiko Singh.
Extended Biography & Contact Information

Summary: By Rachel Fischbach Principal, BraytonHughes Design Studios | August 14, 2022

Title: Cultural Intelligence is The Bridge to Hospitality
Text:
A few weeks ago, I was in New York City, crossing the Brooklyn Bridge. I felt the slightest sway, a barely perceptible give as I drove. As anyone who has driven or trekked across the 139-year-old span knows, I was experiencing the bridge's secret strength. It was designed to be flexible and give a little but never fail in its mission to connect people.
This is an important lesson for the hospitality industry as we recover from the last few challenging years. Resiliency involves building flexibility into our foundations. For our business – the people business – this means developing our ability to serve and connect people from all backgrounds and cultures. We need to sway a bit and understand where our employees and guests are coming from and what they need.
Some might disagree and say that this is a time when our industry needs to focus on "fundamentals." They will tell you we can't afford "nice-to-haves," and "I don't have time for this. I have work to do!"
But I'm here to tell you, now is exactly the time to invest in Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI). Or what I call Cultural Intelligence. I resist the notion that a commitment to Cultural Intelligence is a "nice to have." Our employees and guests have had two years for deep reflection. They are making decisions based on personal values and where they feel welcomed and most comfortable. They are not putting up with employers who have not invested in DEI and improved their cultural intelligence.
According to recent research by PwC Global, a sense of "high belonging" translates into a 50 percent drop in turnover and a 75 percent reduction in sick days. The same report cites 86 percent of millennial females and 74 percent of millennial males closely review a company's DEI policy before agreeing to an interview or accepting a job offer.
Meanwhile, McKinsey researchers found such a shift in customer habits that they titled a report of their findings "The Rise of the Inclusive Consumer." They found that two out of three Americans say their social values shape their shopping choices.
These potential employees and guests can tell who gets it and who doesn't. If we don't get it, we lose them. Cultural Intelligence is now a core competency.
Employees and guests are making decisions based on personal values and where they feel welcomed and most comfortable.
So How Do We Build Cultural Intelligence?
On an individual level, the first step is to listen with the intent not to respond, but to understand. We must hear what people are telling us about how they want to be treated. Example: When we ask our people how they endured COVID, let's take the time to hear what they say. Did they lose a loved one? Did they nurse a partner back to health? Did they get sick?
Understanding their perspectives can help every interaction going forward, whether it's being sensitive to their grieving process or anticipating how to handle an interaction with a guest who wants to engage them in a vaccination debate. Authentic inclusivity starts at the top. Leaders set the right tone when they demonstrate an honest commitment to listening and learning.
This is only one small example. Every conversation that starts with real listening will elicit dozens more insights and even more opportunities to create an inclusive workplace.
I want to be clear. Having more Cultural Intelligence doesn't mean we have to always agree. It means being mindful of perspectives. The more we can gain an understanding of those around us, the more flexible – and resilient – we can be.
On an organizational level, the first step is to understand that policies and procedures don't mean much in and of themselves. They need some teeth.
My organization, the Multicultural Foodservice & Hospitality Alliance (MFHA), this year partnered with the National Restaurant Association, the National Restaurant Association Education Foundation and Cornell School of Hotel Administration to measure the effectiveness of DEI practices in the restaurant industry. Almost all – 98 percent – of the businesses surveyed had codified diversity policies and procedures. Whether these policies had a positive impact, however, is not so clear.
Of the 2,000 current employees in the restaurant industry surveyed, only 62 percent said the DEI policies in their workplaces had a positive impact. Among the former employees surveyed, that percentage fell to 40 percent.
One takeaway? There is a gap between a company's perceptions about its DEI effectiveness and its employees'actual experiences. Companies need to work harder to make their DEI policies effective and engage their employees in the effort.
According to new research, only 62 percent of employees in the restaurant industry said their workplace's DEI policies have a positive impact.
This would be true in any context, but in today's tight labor market, it's urgent. The survey also found that job satisfaction improves when employees feel they are respected.
The same coalition that conducted the survey has developed a framework and toolkit for creating more effective DEI policies and programs called "ELEVATE: Menu for Change."
Now, let's talk about the future. Recruitment is a major part of building resilience because it directly affects our employees, managers, and leaders of tomorrow. If we want those future ranks to better reflect the communities where we work and where our employees and guests live, the hard work starts now.
I'm a graduate of Johnson & Wales University, one of the major talent pipelines to our industry. It, and a handful of other big schools, create a streamlined system many of us don't think too much about. It's time to think about how we can cast a wider net.
Here, goals are not enough. If we are committed to creating a broader, more diverse and diversely-talented staff, we need to go out and get it. That means we reach into the communities we want to engage and build relationships with community organizations. We don't just show up and ask for their best and brightest. You don't get too far knocking on someone's door and making demands. We have to knock, be gracious about being invited in, ask questions and listen. And, we need to think about what we can offer these communities to make the relationship worthwhile.
Do they need more internship opportunities? More training? More mentors? We can carve new paths between these communities and our organizations.
This won't be easy, but we have to keep going back. Showing up to one Urban League banquet a year is not good enough. Join boards, speak at events, host gatherings, do the work.
Author Gerry Fernandez, Founder & President of MFHA, with Yolanda Travis, the current owner of the first-ever Black-owned McDonald's.
Taking this a step further, diversity in leadership and ownership is a great way to show, not tell the industry's commitment. This is close to my heart because I have been working to encourage minority ownership in the restaurant industry for many years. Currently, only 9 percent of restaurants are owned by Black Americans, even though they comprise a large proportion of the food industry's workforce. (Note: I write Black, not African-Americans, because not all Black Americans are of African descent. A point for Cultural Intelligence.)
MFHA, with an investment from PepsiCo, created a program called Pathways to recruit and prepare aspiring Black entrepreneurs to take on franchise ownership. Denny's, Smoothie King, and Noodles & Company have joined as partners.
The hotel industry could take on similar initiatives to diversify property ownership. Not only does this expand the talent pool and bring fresh perspectives to leadership, but it also helps underserved communities realize opportunities to create generational wealth. What better way to demonstrate the kind of authentic commitment that employees and customers notice?
Remember that McKinsey report I mentioned above, "The Rise of the Inclusive Consumer?" In it, researchers report that 45 percent of Americans want retailers to actively support Black-owned businesses.
This is good evidence for why I like to say, diversity isn't just about Black and white. It's mostly about green.
Rebuilding after the blows we've taken these past two years is not going to be easy. Neither is rebuilding in a more inclusive, flexible, sustainable way. But we are hospitality people. We are used to tough jobs and hard-to-deliver requests. We can do this. Our industry will be better for it, and our people will be better for it.
Mr. Fernandez, Sr.
Gerry Fernandez is President and Founder of the Multicultural Foodservice & Hospitality Alliance (MFHA), which he formed in 1995 while an executive at General Mills to advance diversity leadership in the restaurant, foodservice and hospitality industry. MFHA has grown to become a Diversity, Equity + Inclusion (DEI) thought leader, serving as a leading resource on cultural competency for more than 50 member companies, ranging from small emerging brands to some of the most well-known names in the industry. A former Trustee of Johnson & Wales University, Mr. Fernandez holds a bachelor's degree in Foodservice Management from the same school, where he also earned a Culinary Arts degree and an honorary doctorate in Business Administration.
Extended Biography & Contact Information

Summary: By Gerald Fernandez, Sr. President & Founder, Multicultural Foodservice & Hospitality Alliance | August 14, 2022

Title: Salman Rushdie está a recuperar
Text:
O escritor britânico Salman Rushdie está no “caminho da recuperação”, dois dias após ter sido apunhalado várias vezes nos Estados Unidos por um jovem norte-americano de origem libanesa, anunciou domingo o seu agente, Andrew Wylie.
Num comunicado citado pelo jornal Washington Post, o agente disse que Rushdie já não está sob respiração assistida e que “o caminho da recuperação” começou.
“Os ferimentos são graves, mas o seu estado evolui numa boa direção”, acrescentou o agente do autor de “Os Verículos Satânicos”, atacado na sexta-feira no centro cultural de Chautauqua, no estado norte-americano de Nova Iorque, quando se preparava para dar uma palestra.
Wylie acrescentou ainda que o processo de recuperação do escritor será longo.
Esfaqueado uma dezena de vezes no pescoço e no abdómen, Salman Rushdie, 75 anos, permanece hospitalizado em estado grave, mas no sábado à noite já foi capaz de dizer algumas palavras.
No sábado, Wylie disse que o escritor irá “provavelmente perder um olho”, além de os nervos de um dos seus braços terem sido cortados e de ter sofrido danos no fígado.
Ameaçado de morte desde uma ‘fatwa’ (decreto da lei islâmica) iraniana de 1989, um ano após a publicação de “Os Versículos Satânicos”, Salman Rushdie foi alvo de um ataque que chocou o Ocidente, mas que foi bem recebido por extremistas no Irão e no Paquistão.
O agressor, um jovem norte-americano de origem libanesa, foi hoje presente a um juiz do estado de Nova Iorque, perante o qual se declarou “inocente” de tentativa de homicídio do escritor.
Numa audiência processual no tribunal de Chautauqua, Hadi Matar, 24 anos, acusado de tentativa de homicídio e agressão, compareceu com roupa de prisioneiro, às riscas pretas e brancas, algemado e com uma máscara de proteção individual.
Segundo a acusação, o ataque foi premeditado.
O suspeito, que vive em Nova Jersey, irá comparecer novamente em tribunal em 19 de agosto.
O ataque, visto por muitos como um ataque à liberdade de expressão, foi condenado por líderes mundiais como o Presidente norte-americano, Joe Biden, o primeiro-ministro britânico, Boris Johnson, ou o chefe de Estado francês, Emmanuel Macron.
As vendas do controverso livro de Rushdie dispararam desde sexta-feira e o romance está hoje no 11.º lugar da lista de ‘best sellers’ da plataforma eletrónica de vendas Amazon.
Residente em Nova Iorque há 20 anos, Salman Rushdie tinha começado a retomar uma vida mais ou menos normal enquanto continuava a defender a sátira e a irreverência nos seus livros.
“Os Versículos Satânicos” são considerados pelos muçulmanos radicais como uma blasfémia contra o Alcorão e o Profeta Maomé.
TÓPICOS salman rushdie
Mais Lidas Estudantes portugueses passam férias a ajudar crianças em Cabo Verde Carlos Conceição duplamente premiado em Locarno
Summary: Segunda-feira 15 de agosto de 2022 às 00:45
Author: Profeta Maomé

Text: Un incendie avait été signalé vers 20h00. Title: Sports Late Night
Text:
Ze blikken ook vooruit op de volgende speeldag en werpen een blik op het klassement.
 Op zaterdag en zondag brengt Sports Late Night verslag uit van alle matchen en alle doelpunten van de Jupiler Pro League. Afwisselend gidsen Bart Raes, Gilles De Coster en Joris Brys de kijker door de wedstrijden van de dag, en gaan dieper in op betwistbare fases en de stand van het Belgische voetbal.
 Sports Late Night, elke zaterdag en zondag.

Title: Mies van der Rohe awards 2022
Summary: De ambities van de Mies van der Rohe Awards zijn gericht op de bevordering van en het inzicht in de kwaliteit en de weerspiegeling van de complexiteit van architectuur op vlak van technologische, constructieve, sociale, economische, culturele en esthetische verwezenlijkingen. De winnaar van de Architecture Award van dit jaar is Town House at Kingston University (UK) van Grafton architects, Dublin. Het gebouw vertegenwoordigt de volledigheid van architectonische uitmuntendheid en biedt een emotionele ervaring van binnenuit en door de zuilengalerij met meerdere niveaus van de gevel, waardoor op verschillende niveaus een huiselijke sfeer wordt gecreëerd. La Borda - Cooperative Housing is de winnaar van de Emerging Architecture Award. Het project is gebouwd als een paradijs op huiselijke schaal en creëert een gemeenschap en de materialisatie van de betekenis van gemeenschap.In de tentoonstelling kan je ook de andere 5 finalisten ontdekken:85 Social Housing Units, Cornellà de Llobregat, by
